item.title: Ticket #18302 (Improve child theme file inheritance by introducing a function to ...) updated
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
Patch refreshed. Ignore 18302.2.patch as it accidentally contains other unrelated changes.

18302.2.2.patch​ changes the function name to locate_template_uri() and uses get_template|stylesheet_directory() instead of the constants.

I'm still wondering whether a nicer named template function could be a good idea. locate_template_uri() is rather a technical name and something like get_theme_file() would be nicer for theme developers to use. Suggestions?

item.dc:creator: till
item.description:
I agree with the previous poster while I understand that this is very technical, etc..

I ran into the same issue for the sake of testing, I even set 0777 (yes, I know it's insecure), but the test inside this function still failed. define('FS_METHOD', 'direct'); was my only possible work-around.

Generally, I'm also wondering why a temporary file needs to be created when a is_writable() should suffice?

item.title: Ticket #17807 (get_adjacent_post() doesn't work with custom taxonomies) updated
item.dc:creator: billerickson
item.description:
I've updated my patch to work with the updates from [18478]. I've also created a plugin that simulates this patch for testing, and will post that once it's approved in the repo. It allows you to use functions like be_previous_post_link() and be_get_adjacent_post().

Scribu, I personally don't think it's worth rebuilding get_adjacent_post() and all the related functions to accept query vars other than taxonomy. I think this improvement is needed, and if it other query_vars in get_adjacent_post() become needed then we can generalize it.

item.title: Ticket #18339 (chrome browser - white 'box' overlays text in admin) closed
item.dc:creator: anmari
item.description:
invalid:

Damn - sorry people - missed the dropins - strangely though it was not those.

However I did have some old odd files (zips and code snippets) sitting in plugins folder - I moved them out and cleaned out some and now it's gone. It was around for a few days - seemingly off/on - I don't know which caused the problem or why (all but the dropins were deactivated). I tried putting a few files back to see if I could recreate but could not. Pity - would love to know what caused it. Sometimes the 'box' seemed to 'hover' when scrolling.

... Should have checked on another system first before reporting. I get torn between absolute faith in the quality of WP releases ..and knowing that there are so many varieties of circumstances out there that maybe just maybe I have found a singularity.

item.title: Ticket #15458 (Lazy-load usermeta into the user object) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
Those lines in WP_User::_init_caps() are somehow causing cache pollution. wp_cache_get($id, 'users'), as done in get_userdata(), will sometimes return an object with the wp_xxx_capabilities property set ( where xxx is the current blog id). The value is an empty array. This confuses get_blogs_of_user(), which sees that the property is set and mistakenly thinks the user belongs to the current blog. Since the cache clones objects on set and get this is rather unexpected. Removing the ref assignment avoids the problem.

Tracked this down to a bug in a particular memcached backend. The value was being properly cloned from the cache during get but then that clone was assigned right back into the cache. Dumb. Anyhow, not a core bug so disregard the previous comment.

item.title: Ticket #18347 (links in rss feed for http://core.trac.wordpress.org/report/33 broken) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description: Here's a RSS feed for changesets: ​http://core.trac.wordpress.org/timeline?changeset=on&max=50&authors=&daysback=90&format=rss - That comes from the Timeline page.

item.title: Ticket #18347 (links in rss feed for http://core.trac.wordpress.org/report/33 broken) updated
item.dc:creator: dd32
item.description:
Trac expects reports to list tickets rather than changesets/comments/attachments, as such, I don't think theres any way to fix this without hacking the template code..

Report 33 is designed to be a temporary-use report for generating the contributors to each release rather than as a general-use report.. I'm sure theres another feed for commits which should be used instead.

item.title: Ticket #18347 (links in rss feed for http://core.trac.wordpress.org/report/33 broken) updated
item.dc:creator: SergeyBiryukov
item.description: Component, Milestone changed

item.title: Ticket #18347 (links in rss feed for http://core.trac.wordpress.org/report/33 broken) created
item.dc:creator: SidHarrell
item.description:
It's probably more of a trac bug, but the links in the feed: ​http://core.trac.wordpress.org/report/33?asc=1&format=rss look like this: ​http://core.trac.wordpress.org/ticket/0000018517 when they should look like this: ​http://core.trac.wordpress.org/changeset/18517

I could probably pull it into a script, covert it to an object, change all the links, and republish it on my server, but it's a time investment I don't want to make if I don't have to. The workaround would be to subscribe to a mailing list for just the commits, but I couldn't find that in a google search. I subscribed to the mailing list for tickets, but it's like trying to drink from the firehose. I don't have time to look at all that traffic. Thanks.

item.title: Ticket #15458 (Lazy-load usermeta into the user object) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
$this->caps = &$this->data->{$this->cap_key};
if ( ! is_array( $this->caps ) )
	$this->caps = array();

Those lines in WP_User::_init_caps() are somehow causing cache pollution. wp_cache_get($id, 'users'), as done in get_userdata(), will sometimes return an object with the wp_xxx_capabilities property set ( where xxx is the current blog id). The value is an empty array. This confuses get_blogs_of_user(), which sees that the property is set and mistakenly thinks the user belongs to the current blog. Since the cache clones objects on set and get this is rather unexpected. Removing the ref assignment avoids the problem.

item.title: Ticket #18346 (orderby="title" does not work properly in WP_Query) closed
item.dc:creator: jobjorn
item.description:
invalid:

Sorry about that - of course WordPress uses whichever sort order MySQL uses. If you are having a similar problem, you'll just have to change your character collation - I changed from utf8_general_ci to utf8_swedish_ci on the column "post_title" in wp_posts and now it works as it should do (even putting ä in the end).

item.title: Ticket #18346 (orderby="title" does not work properly in WP_Query) created
item.dc:creator: jobjorn
item.description:
I am running a homemade plugin that displays an alphabetical post index. It didn't take me long to notice that "Äppelpaj med knäcktäcke" was sorted immediately after "Ajvarpasta med solrosfrön", that is, Ä after A rather than at the end of the alphabet - the swedish alphabet is like the english one but with three extra letters, Å Ä Ö, at the end. Since I did not really expect WordPress to handle the quirks of all languages, I ignored this.

However. It soon turned out that "Asiatisk gryta med tofu och plommon" was sorted after "Äppelpaj med knäcktäcke", meaning that the sort goes AÄA. Ä is treated as an A by WordPress.

In the get_posts loop, I'm adding a new header for each letter, based on when the first letter of the post changes from the first letter of the previous post. But since WordPress seems to treat Ä as A, and PHP rightly does not, I end up with two "A" headers with an "Ä" header in the middle.

This can't be right, can it?

I'm attaching my little (not entirely finished) plugin.

item.title: Ticket #18340 (Quickedit on Spam Comments adds approve and unapprove) updated
item.dc:creator: ocean90
item.description:
IMO spam comments are very similar to unapproved comments. There aren't trashed, they only get as status spam. So I know it from most of the plugins. I must decide if it's really a spam comment or not.

If they are trashed automatically then no Quick Edit is possible, that's fine.

+1 for Edit and Approve ( or Unspam)

item.title: Ticket #18345 (Problem with query_posts) closed
item.dc:creator: SergeyBiryukov
item.description:
invalid:

​http://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/query_posts#Usage_Note:

The wp_query object will generate a new SQL query using your parameters. When you do this, WordPress ignores the other parameters it receives via the URL (such as page number or category). If you want to preserve that information, you can use the $query_string global variable in the call to query_posts().

Try this: 

global $query_string;
query_posts( $query_string . '&cat=1' );

item.title: Ticket #18344 (3.2.1 Permalinks Rule Missing For page/2?cat=1) updated
item.dc:creator: soliver
item.description:
I have checked various other blogs running 3.2.1 and they all have the same problem, /page/2?cat=1 is directly accessible, generating duplicate content issues on a large scale.

Demo Link: ​http://www.datingsolutions.biz/page/2/?cat=1

This was not possible in previous Wordpress version, therefore I would consider it as a bug.

item.title: Ticket #18345 (Problem with query_posts) updated
item.dc:creator: kaspy2011
item.description: I have the same problem.

item.title: Ticket #18340 (Quickedit on Spam Comments adds approve and unapprove) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
Replying to ocean90:

IMHO spam comments are very similar to trashed comments. The only difference is that they were trashed automatically by a plugin or by matching a word, number of URLs, etc.

Unapproved comments are "undecided". That's why we have Edit and Approve as a combined editing action for them. This happens often in the workflow.

We should either extend the Edit and Approve to spam comments or completely remove editing there.

item.title: Ticket #18345 (Problem with query_posts) created
item.dc:creator: toniboni88
item.description:
When I use the function "query_posts" --> ​http://codex.wordpress.org/Function_Reference/query_posts" before the loop, I see correctly the first posts, but if I click on other pages I look the same articles, even if I go on the last page.

Example: 

query_posts( 'cat=1' );

item.title: Ticket #18344 (3.2.1 Permalinks Rule Missing For page/2?cat=1) created
item.dc:creator: soliver
item.description:
Hello,

after upgrading to 3.2.1 the index.php does not rewrite ?cat=1 when added to the pagination. e.g. domain.com/page/2?cat=1

Info: Custom Permalink Structore (Most Common): /%postname%.html

Normally this (domain.com/page/2?cat=1) would resolve to domain.com/category/uncategorized/page/2 - but it no longer does and is directly accessible.

This will cause duplicate content errors, if you do not use canonical links and is therefore a major bug and can lead to various Google problems.

Yes, I have temporarily disabled all plugins and checked this on multiple servers with the same result, but I need a 2nd opinion on this - can someone verify the problem for me?

Thank you, Oliver

item.title: Ticket #18343 (Commas in taxonomy term causes misdisplay in taxonomy metabox on post ...) created
item.dc:creator: yianniy
item.description:
If a taxonomy term has commas in it, it will be displayed incorrectly in the taxonomy metabox on the post edit page. Instead of displaying the term, it will display as multiple terms broken where the commas are.

For instance the term 'Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870' becomes the three terms 'Dumas' 'Alexandre' and '1802-1870'.

If the post is updated, it's terms will be replaced with displayed terms instead of the original term.

item.dc:creator: azaozz

fixed:

Yes, as quicktags is properly enqueued now. Still it is being enqueued mid-page so the dequeue should be done early in a footer action. However I think the underlying problem was fixed too as quicktags is multi-instance by default.

item.title: Ticket #18341 (Previewing posts causes saves and updates to freeze in Safari 5.1) updated
item.dc:creator: duck_
item.description: Possibly a Webkit bug and duplicate of #12778

item.title: Ticket #18341 (Previewing posts causes saves and updates to freeze in Safari 5.1) created
item.dc:creator: chrisrudzki
item.description:
Previewing posts causes subsequent saves and updates to freeze, resulting in an endless spinning wheel, in Safari 5.1. The issue arises under different conditions, depending on the version of Mac OS X that Safari 5.1 is running on.

Steps to Reproduce:

Safari 5.1 on Mac OS X 10.6.8

  1. Edit or create a draft/post, and then click Save Draft or Update
  2. Preview draft/post
  3. Close preview window or don’t close preview window. Doesn’t matter.
  4. Clicking on Save Draft or Update results in endless spinning wheel

Safari 5.1 on Mac OS X 10.7

  1. Edit or create a draft, and then click Save Draft
  2. Preview draft
  3. Don’t close preview window
  4. Clicking on Save Draft or Publish results in endless spinning wheel

Issue reports: ​http://en.forums.wordpress.com/topic/freezing-when-i-try-to-save-a-draft ​http://en.forums.wordpress.com/topic/freezing-when-i-try-to-save-a-draft-1 ​http://en.forums.wordpress.com/topic/how-do-i-fix-repeated-freezing-and-other-new-problems

There are also reports of the same issue occurring with other browsers, such as Chrome: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/freezing-when-saving-a-draft ​http://en.forums.wordpress.com/topic/freezes-when-saving-draft

However, I'm not able to reproduce this in Firefox 5.0.1 or Chrome 13.0.782.107 under OS X 10.6.8 or 10.7

item.title: Ticket #15458 (Lazy-load usermeta into the user object) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
Keywords changed

lazy-load.2.diff​:

  • updated wp_insert_user() and wp_update_user() to use WP_User::get_data_by() instead of get_userdata()
  • sanitize_user_object() is deprecated. Sanitization is handled in __get()

Everything seems to work.

PS: The patch can be applied using patch -p1, instead of patch -p0.

item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description: Looking at both this ticket and #18337, seems the best solution wouldn't be to move postboxes when switching columns but to move the columns (the containers) themselves. Same for the dashboard: can make it auto-switch depending on the screen width.

item.title: Ticket #15458 (Lazy-load usermeta into the user object) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
perhaps we should standardize on using a get() or get_meta() accessor so we can handle dashed keys

Well, you can always do get_user_meta( $user->ID, 'some-key', true ) or just $user->{'some-key'}.

item.title: Ticket #15458 (Lazy-load usermeta into the user object) updated
item.dc:creator: scribu
item.description:
lazy-load.diff​:

  • _fill_user(), _fill_single_user() and _fill_many_users() are gone.
  • get_user_metavalues() is deprecated
  • introduces a static method WP_User::get_data_by() which handles all fields, including 'id'
  • handles the case in get_blogs_of_user()

What it doesn't handle yet: wp_update_user(). This means that most fields in user-edit.php aren't updated anymore.

item.title: lazy-load.diff attached to Ticket #15458
item.dc:creator: scribu
